newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatia, Hungary in $80 mln 400 kV power line deal.
newsitem.headline: Croatia, Hungary in $80 mln 400 kV power line deal.

text.p: Croatian electricity utility HEP and its Hungarian counterpart MVM signed an $80 million deal to build a 400 kV power transmission line between the two countries, daily Vjesnik reported on Friday.

The portion of the work in Croatia between Zerjavinci and the Hungarian border would amount to some $50 million, it said. Hungary will shoulder the cost of its own section of the 168.50 km power line, to the town of Heviz.

Croatia has a key position on the power transmission corridor to the southeast of Europe. The new line would link it directly to the central and eastern European power grid, enabling an alternative route for electricity imports.
It would also provide indirect access to the west European network, now possible only through neighbouring Slovenia.
